titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Finished Lessing’s tract upon Epigrams—began his observations upon Catullus— Evening at the Princess Henry’s— Mrs: A. there for the first time, for several months.— Reversi with Madame de Hagen. M. de Rothenburg, and the Comte de Caraman.

2. We went with Mr: Richards this forenoon, to see the China-Manufacture.— I saw nothing however, but what I had seen there before— We went in the Evening to see the fire-works, but found them postponed— Mr: Garlike called to see me this Evening— First fires this Season.
3. Busy in writing to send by my brother— At the play this afternoon.— The portrait of the mother; or the private Comedy—by Schroder— Did not well understand it.

4. Finished reading Lessing’s observations upon Martial— They are amusing and ingenious.— Frederic left me. Visit this afternoon to the Count and Countess Golowkin.— Evening to see the fire-works a couple of miles out of town— Exhibited by the young men of the military school—annually.

5. Continue writing letters for my brother to take to America.— Weather very fine— Letter from my brother, at Dessau. Evening at the Casino— Finished Lessing upon the Priapeia and Greek Anthology.— Read likewise two Acts of Shakespear’s Henry 6. Second part.

6. Finished the first volume of Lessing’s works, and read a few more pages in Buchholz—whom I still find tedious, intricate in style and very partial in his narrative.— Busily writing a great part of the day.— At the play this Evening to see Kabale und Liebe, a tragedy of Schiller.— Their style of acting is less animated and vehement even, than that of the English stage.— They very seldom perform tragedies.— The moral tendency of this play is bad.

7. Morning occupation as usual for Sunday— Long walk.— Not out after dinner; the weather being dull. Read a couple of acts of 2d: part Henry 6.— Am reading also, in the morning Lessing’s Nathan der Weise, and as much as I can of Buchholz’s History.

8. Busily writing yet— Evening at Bellevue— The company large— Madame de Grappendorf & Mrs: A. the only Ladies invited.— Whist with Madame de G. Count Neale and Count d’Esternon, son to the former french Minister whom Mirabeau so often mentions in his letters.

9. Wrote to my mother.— The bookseller brought me Rabener’s Satyres. cursorily looked over them— Liked them less than I expected— At the Casino part of the Evening.— At home the remainder.— Mlle: Neale.— Finished the second part of Henry 6.
10. Letter writing in the morning.— Walk before dinner— At the Casino this Evening— Began to read the third part of Henry 6. but could not reach much of it— Mrs: A. being very unwell.
11. Mrs: A. had a very bad night, with a severe head ache.— Letter to J. Gardner.— Short walk before dinner: and again after— At the Casino— Continued Henry 6. 3d: part.
12. Stormy day— Mrs: A. went to Charlottenburg— Walk to the Mill bridge— Mr: Richards dined with us. Read preface to Rabener’s Satires— Finished the 3d. part of Henry 6.
13. Weather growing cold— Wrote to Mr: Murray.— Reading Buchholz—Lessing—Rabener, and in the Evening to Mrs: A— Gillies’s history of Greece.

14. Letters from Mr: King, Mr: Murray, and my brother— Visit of Miss Neale to Mrs: A.—Sunday Morning. A young Dutchman, named Washington, called on me— States himself as a relation of the General: and is desirous of going to America— Evening at Bellevue— Whist With Mlle: de Hagen; Count Neale, and M. Gualtieri—an officer— Miss Borck, took a likeness of Mrs: A.

15. Called at the Casino before dinner, to read the Papers— Miss Neale— Evening at Princess Henry’s.— Reversi, with Madame de Hagen, Madame de Sartoris, and Mlle: de Marwitz— Rheumatism threatens me again.

16. At Mr: Schickler’s in the forenoon. Endeavouring to write, but not to much purpose.— Short walk. In the afternoon, Mlle: Bishopswerder, and Mlle: Wartensleben paid visits to Mrs: Adams.— Finished the first volume of Gillies’s History of Greece, and began upon the second— Have an unthankful task upon my hands— But how to extricate myself from it?

17. Fine weather— Engaged in writing a new and useless memorial. Walk before dinner— At the Casino in the afternoon— At home, reading in Gillies’s history of Greece— Finished at length Lessing’s Nathan der Weise. I see not what Moses Mendelssohn thought so wonderfully fine in it, unless it be that the greatest character is a Jew.

18. Went with Mrs: A. this morning to the Exhibition at the Academy.— Met the Prince and Princess Radziwill there— It contains nothing remarkably good.— A few tolerable, and many very indifferent paintings. Some statues and wax figures; chiefly of the king and queen, more or less resembling. drawings, carpets, &c. Long walk afterwards with Mrs: A— At the Casino towards Evening.— Read further in Gillies— Began Lessing’s Tragedy entitled, Miss Sara Sampson.
19. Rained this day, so as prevented me from walking out— Wrote a little— Evening at Bellevue— Whist with Madame de Grappendorf, Mr: Helbig, and M. de Sydow.

20. Letter to Mr: Murray— Walk in the Park.— Visit in the afternoon from Baron Engeström and his Lady. Reading as before—Buchholz in the morning, and Gillies in the Evening— Also a book (4th.) of Paradise lost.

21. Forenoon employed according to custom— Walk in the park. Mrs: Adams, on a visit to Mrs: Brown, who returned yesterday from Charlottenburg, for the Season.— Evening and supper at Madame d’Engeström’s— About 25 persons—a small company here— Among the rest, the Archbishop of Gnesen, who delights in telling anecdotes of Frederic II.— Told us among the rest of his ordering a Statuary to furnish him by with a Theseus abandoned by Ariadne— The sculptor told him, it must be Ariadne, abandoned by Theseus— “No objections, if you please, said the king, but do the business as you are ordered.”
22. Busy most of the day— At the Casino— Mrs: Brown and her daughters, with Mr: Richards passed the Evening with us.

23. Finished Lessing’s Tragedy of Miss Sara Sampson, and began his Philotas.— Visit from Mr: Garlike with Messrs: Livingstone and Arbuthnot: Gentlemen attending the English Prince Augustus, who arrived here yesterday.— Evening at Mrs: Brown’s— Mr: Arbuthnot was there— The Prince travels under the title of Comte de Diepholz.

24. Returned the visits of yesterday— Dined at Count Schulenburg’s, with what they call a small company (25 persons) of Gentlemen and Ladies— At half past five called on Count Haugwitz—to urge him to finish without further delays my business here; in the renewal of the Treaty— He said there could be no objection.— I am to call upon him again on Saturday the 27th.— Evening at Countess Eichstett’s.— Reversi, with Madame de Hagen, Mlle: Marwitz, and the Marquis de Musquiz.— Letters from Mr: Murray. Visit in the morning from the Comte de Caraman.

25. Finished Lessing’s Philotas, and began his Emilia Gallotti.— Fine day. Evening at Bellevue— Whist with Madame de Pritwitz. the Chancellor Goldbeck, and M. de Sydow.— The Prince told me a story about the Marquis de Bouillé and his Son.— He is no friend to the french emigrants.
26. Very closely engaged in writing, all the morning, and great part of the Evening. Found only leisure for a short walk.— Miss Brown here part of the Evening.

27. Letter to Mr: Murray.— At 5 o’clock in the afternoon, by appointment called upon Count Haugwitz. He read the note, which I purpose presenting in reply to the Ministry of the Cabinet, and professed himself much satisfied with it.— However, I do not expect that it will do any good. He made some mention of Kosciuszko, who he says is now gone from Paris— Does not appear at all satisfied with France at present— Remainder of the Evening at Mrs: Brown— Mr: Livingston there; an old Scotchman.— entertaining.— The king of Prussia has raised the pay of his troops. 2. groshen every 5 days to each man.

28. From the variety of my occupations, attend not sufficiently to any of them.— Reading this forenoon.— Walk in the park— Mrs: Brown at tea with Mrs: Adams.— Expects the Doctor home to-morrow.— At the Casino— Letter from my brother at Hamburg.

29. Wrote to General Washington.— The Weather after having been several weeks remarkably fine appears now to change— Dr: Brown got home.— Visit from Miss Neale— Evening at the Princess Henry’s— Whist with Madame de Marwitz—Madame de Riedesel and Mr: Livingstone.— The turkish Ambassador died this day.

30. Called by appointment at 1. o’clock upon Count Finkenstein, and delivered him my new Note. Convinced myself more than ever, notwithstanding what Count Haugwitz says, that they mean to delay.— Visit this afternoon from the young Countess Brühl to Mrs: A.— Called in the Evening upon Dr: Brown; who while I was at his house, returned from Potsdam— Reading again in Gillies.

31. At a party of tea and cards at the Dom Herr (Canon) von Rochow’s—knew but little of the Company. Remainder of the Evening at Bellevue— Prince Ferdinand himself being unwell, did not make his appearance— Whist with Prince Radziwill, the Baron de Reck and Baron Geertz.— Mrs: A. did not go, being somewhat unwell.

Day. Rise between 7 and 8— German reading till 10. breakfast. Write till 2. Walk. Dine between 3. and 4. Evening in Company abroad, or reading to Mrs: A. at home.— My German reading this month has been small.— Only a couple of volumes of Lessing, and Part of Buchholz last volume, which I hope however to finish in a few days.— I have read him with more attention than such a miserable historian deserved— But it is the reign of Frederic 2. that he relates.
